question:
Can you tell me why there are so few trades in my test?
i was expecting several hundred?
answer:
Always best to start a backtest without any constraints (e.g. VIX), and then gradually refine. There were long periods of time when VIX was less than 20.

Always best to start a backtest over a shorter duration (it's quicker, if nothing else!) and then build from there.

For selling naked puts (even on SPY) always best to start with a silly amount of capital, to ensure you don't accidentally run out of margin.

For longer duration trades, they won't show up in the test results, unless you toggle 'close open trades on test completion'.But more generally; if you start 'simple' and build complexity, you'll have a better idea as to what setting you changed, which caused the backtest to give 'unexpected' results.

question: When entering a fixed premium for a Short Put Spread with for example $0.5 for the short and $0.1 for the long I see in the trade log that OO is taking premiums that are over $0.5 for the short. Even trades with $0.6 and $0.7 which should not happen. Is there a function to tell OO that $0.5 is the MAX premium and should not go higher than this and only look for lower premiums instead?
answer:
Would something like a 'max. credit' filter work?

Note - some potential trades will be filtered out, as the nearest available strikes to 50 cents might be 30 cents and 65 cents, in which case the 65 would be chosen for the candidate trade.

The OO selection is for the 'nearest strike'. There aren't options to choose (instead) 'next strike below' or 'next strike above' (and if there were, that would make the interface a lot more complicated!)

question:
As the title says I get pretty big differences when backtesting 0DTE strategies and using "Require Two Consecutive Hits at Stop Loss". In one instance the p/l almost doubled.

Can someone explain exactly why the difference is so big?

Also while I'm asking does anyone know if this is similar to using a double bid/ask order for the Stop (at least that's what IBKR calls it)?
answer:
It's not the same as IBKR's double bid.

Some positions will have spready prices, and NBBO and mid could fluctuate wildly during opening, and in other times of high volatility.

A cautious approach is not to use OO double tap (two sequential minute closes) for SLs.

If you are trading longer-expiry trades, and would manually exit (not with a SL order) when price reaches your limit zone, it may be appropriate. It will very much depend on the particular backtest, your approach to trading, etc.

question: The trades executed for 30- and 90 days time frames are different. Is that normal?  If I do a 30 days time frame, I get 4 trades executed with 1 losing trade.  If I use 90 days, I get 6 trades executed with 0 losing trades.  Also, 90 days make 2 more trades in the last 30 days than the 30 days time frame.  Please can you clarify why trades over the same period in different timeframes don't correspond?
answer:
Run the backtest:
(a) with 1 contract (so that it enters 'whenever it can', rather than only 'if it has spare capital'
(b) use the 'close open trades on test completion' toggle, to understand where you might be at current date

This will probably give you a better insight into the trade ...

question: Hi all. I am trying to figure out the difference in adding "Leg quantity" in the "Legs" section, vs keeping it at 1 and adding max contracts per trade. Looking at an iron condor, It shows very different results with adding 4 legs (in the "legs section), vs 1 leg but 4 contracts. I don't understand, are they not the same trade set up in reality?
answer:
Hey there! The difference is that your slippages, fees, etc are applied to a single "tranche" of the trade. Your trailing stops and closing orders are also based per tranche
look at the premium and closing cost columns in the trade log and compare those to your PT/SL
The second setup is what you want; this is how the software was designed to work
The per-leg quantities are for butterflies, etc., where the leg quantities are uneven (1-2-1, etc).

question:
Hi. I need some help with Stop Loss in "Use Profit Actions"
I Have IF and Initial stop = $3 (as example)
I want to move the stop:
to -$1 as soon as I get 10% "At Profit Target"
to $0 as soon as I get 20% "At Profit Target"
to $1 as soon as I get 30% "At Profit Target"

So what values should I put to "Adjust Stop Loss To"
answer:
You can't, insofar that you're 'mixing' % and $.

The Profit Action Stop Loss is 'relative to current (triggering) price', but if the profit is 10%, who knows whether that's 2$, or 5$ - so it's not possible to know where the SL should now be.

You might want to consider:
- PT 2$, SL to 3$
- PT 4$, SL to 4$
- PT 6$, SL to 5$
... or somesuch

question: I can't find a reason why this date is missing.
answer:
It could be a couple of things: Not enough Margin to support the trade (typical mostly for selling puts & calls).
The exact DTE button is selected, and there were not trades that fit that DTE.
The padlock next to the strike legs is selected. This is the exact strike offset ‚Äî it is padlocked by default but you can uncheck it. If it is left on (default), the trade will only execute if there is an option at that strike.

question: What's the difference between "per trade" and "per lot?"
answer:
Per lot = a single quantity of your trade with the quantity of each contract = leg quantity of the strategy setup
A trade could have 1000 lots, depending on your settings for max contracts and allocation percentage
Per lot is the average/min/max as if you ran your trade with max contracts = 1

question: Trying to test an iron condor strategy that would stop out when one side price is at 110% of the ENTIRE sale premium.  E.g. Sell IC for $2, stop out if call side or put side reaches $2.10.  Is there a way to do this?

question: How do I test a strategy with trades every other week? I can only figure out daily, weekly and monthly.

question: Is there a way to select strikes for the fly wings based on a % away from the short strike? i.e. Tests from 10 years ago would have different results for a 70 point width for SPX vs today. SPX was trading at a lower level back then. Further, is there a way to make sure the widths are equal so it is not a broken wing if I was to use something like delta.
answer:
Best approach, run 4 different backtests..
A. 2013-2015. 20 offset 10 wide
B. 2014-2017, 30 offset, 15 wide
etc.
Combine in Portfolio

Note that butterflies from 10 years ago will behave very different to butterflies these days
